commentBody: Beat my PB by nearly 2 minutes. 9:08!

I did indeed GO WITH THE FLOW,
and I went much too quickly
for my solving pleasure.
I was disappointed to find 
that my winter solstice present 
was a large themeless Tuesday. 

I really hope everyone else's mileage varied.

Lumps of coal Wednesday?

I saw the title and figured it had something to do with rivers.  It actually had to do with nothing.  As I was solving, I realized I wasn't seeing the theme as I was going along, and this was going to be one of those themes that absolutely had nothing to do with the solve.  I guessed I'd figure it out after I finished.

Turns out there wasn't any theme.  So why bother with a title when it doesn't really mean anything?

I'm not a big fan of Sunday themeless puzzles.  It's been a while, and I thought maybe they decided to finally drop them.  This one played nicely, though, and I guess that if we have to put up with themeless Sundays once in a while, this one wasn't that bad.  

Some missteps and pauses:  PINK MANGO for PINKBERRY.  There is a froyo chain called Red Mango...I don't recall ever seeing PINK MANGO, though.  I guess I mixed up the two somehow.

WRYER or wrier?  Or drier?  Or dryer?

The stringed garment (APRON) wasn't a TALLIT, the Jewish prayer shawl.  And it had to be plural anyway.

OMG for FTW, the latter of which I'm not likely to ever use.

And on a happy note, it was nice to see my wife's current position shouted out at 86A (LAW CLERK), which she will be until mid-February, when she finally gets to retire!

MOWED for HEWED.
This was the easiest Sunday I‚Äôve ever done. Set a Sunday PR of under 17 (used to be like 25). Very amused by the hints today! Great puzzle.
Fun puzzle that took me little time to complete. My only comment is that I prefer themed puzzles. Themeless is akin to drinking a nonalcoholic beer without the accompanying buzz.
That probably was the easiest Sunday puzzle I have ever completed - less than half my usual time. Maybe it was an early Christmas present. Even so, I enjoyed it.
Congrats on landing a themeless Sunday, Adrian! It was a pleasurable jaunt though I prefer more of a challenge. Now what am I going to do with the rest of my evening? ;)

Almost, but not quite a personal best. Probably could have beaten my own record if I hadn't stopped to admire a few entries that got filled in by themselves on the crossings. 

I enjoyed every bit of this puzzle, especially the longer-than-Sunday-usual entries that were still clued very accessibly (to me). Made me feel super smart. I knew it was going to be a good day when it started out with the crab pot show in 1A.

Well, on the bright side, that was a new Sunday best....  by very, very, very far. 

I kept waiting and waiting for a fun theme or tricky trick. I eventually tried to PERISHTHETHOUGHT that it might be my first ever Sunday themeless. I honestly didn't know that could happen but alas, here we are. 

The other bright side is that my lucky husband is going to get to hear me sing, "Ain't no sunshine" to him for the next many hours. I promise to try very hard to not change the words to "Ain't no Sunday when the theme is gone... " but I am famous for changing words, so I can only promise to try, not to do. 

And to be clear, I don't think this was a bad puzzle. It's a very fine themeless puzzle. Just not what I hope for on a Sunday. But since I finished it so absurdly early, I guess I can head to the archives for a proper Sunday fix.  ;-) 

Congrats to Mr. Johnson for achieving his goal.
Last Sunday's theme was such a fiasco that the editors have given up on them altogether.

Better time than usual for me, just over 28 minutes. Got tripped up by the SOBE/LITEBRITES crossing as I was not familiar with either, but B made the most sense there. Ended up finding a typo later on in the puzzle - IT CANT HURT to double check, I guess.

userLocation: The Other Side Of The World
commentBody: Sounds like a few, but definitely my PB for a Sunday‚Ä¶ could‚Äôve shaved a few more if I was more wry than dry‚Ä¶

I'll take Adrian's smooth themeless flow over last Sunday's tortured Art Heist anytime.  Today's really did flow nicely, with no obscure names, gluey bits, or cutesy clues.

I accept the occasional "easy" puzzle as one of those gifts like a work meeting ending 30 minutes early: you finish fast and get a half hour back. When you're my age, you take it.
How refreshing after last week‚Äôs all-time clunker. May have been a little *too* easy for a Sunday (or I was just very lucky) but still an enjoyable fill.
Delighted to get back to a classic, unfussy Sunday solve. Needed that after last week.
A reprieve after last week‚Äôs puzzling puzzle. I enjoying looking at the completed puzzle with those long clues all fitting together.
Great puzzle, Adrian!  Congratulations on your themeless Sunday debut. Very smooth solving after I gave up trying to figure out a theme and decided to justb‚Äúgo with the flow.‚Äù

Well, there was a rather Christmasy theme with the competing earworms of Frosty and Rudolph schnoodling together to make: 

Frosty the Snowman had a very shiny nose,
Rudolph the Reindeer was a jolly happy soul.
They went on a dinnerdate to Pinkberry
and on bended snowball did Frosty propose.
He gave jolly Rudolph a ring of coal,
and Santa officiated (he goes with the floes!)

Then one foggy Christmas eve,
Santa came to say
"Rudolph will your partner and you
drive the sleigh? I've had a few
too many bellinis
after jog-trotting  Equatorial Guinea
and if I drove who knows what may ensue?
Perish the thought
but I ain't like what I ought."

Frosty the Snowman knew the sun
was hot down there
but he said "Let's run and have some fun
before I drip drip drip
down to my underwear!"

Well anyway, I think I'll stick to my day job (not songwriting). Very wintry, holiday feel though, hot cocoa, letters to Santa, dripping icicles and all that. Dear Santa, please give me an earworm removal kit for Christmas: these Christmas jingles are killing me!

I have completed the puzzle, have checked it for accuracy 5 times (yes, I Googled once I was finished to find the solution), then had my husband and son check it for me and we all come to the same conclusion that I have completed it correctly, yet I keep getting the "close but not quite" message. Has this happened to anyone else? If I lose my streak I will be bereft and I can not understand how to fix it.
Got almost all of the puzzle, and without using Google. Am I really getting better at this? But everyone is saying how easy it is. *Sigh*
Enjoyed this puzzle after having to wave the white flag last week. FTW was new to me, lol‚ÄîI had entered ‚ÄòOMG‚Äô at first.  Boy, am I a dinosaur.

Santa uses the chimney. It soots him just fine!

(But sometimes he gets the flue.)
My first Sunday under an hour! Great puzzle.

Bring a newish member of the PART B Medicare club, and seeing that crossed with DOLLAR TREE‚Ä¶, it felt like a tiny bleak theme:

Come to the dollar store! They‚Äôre having a special on cholecystectomies, three for $5. 
Bring two friends, and be sure to use EXPRESS CHECKOUT.
If, PERISH THE THOUGHT, your advantage plan has denied coverage for your hip replacement, fear not, the dollar store is doing a special on those next month.
They have medications too, cheap, a real LIFESAVER when your part D has reached some limit or other.

If you desire an ALTERNATE ENDING for the saga of obtaining health care without needing to use the dollar store, consider who you vote for.

Or you could try a LETTER TO SANTA.
What a breath of fresh air after last week

What's up with all of these unorthodox pans this week? Saut√© pans and now crepe pans??

That's my only gripe with today's xword. I don't care that people here are saying that it was easy, I appreciated it after last Sunday's mess.
The 80s babies / 90s kids have entered the chat. SOBEs and LITEBRITES were the most delightful gimmes.

FTW stumped me. Guessing, ‚Äúfeel the win‚Äù?

My other sticking point: Caitlin's description of MOANIN' is exactly right‚Äî except the Jon Hendriks lyrics are almost never heard. I‚Äôve heard and performed this tune 100 times, but didn‚Äôt recognize the line. When I see ‚Äújazz standard‚Äú and ‚Äúlyric‚Äú in a clue, I assume the lyrics are going to be familiar!
Wooo my first completed Sunday without any hints or lookups!hookups! 34:58
Easy peasy?  Not a PB but close.  Straight through top to bottom and then circle back to catch a couple of typos‚Ä¶. Nice Sunday‚Ä¶
What an absolutely fantastic puzzle, probably my favourite of the year. So many clever clues and unexpected phrases. A real Christmas gift and a treat, thank you.

Clearly, this was a response to the fact everybody hated the last Sunday puzzle, and with good reason. I broke my personal Sunday record with a time in the mid-teens, but I almost feel like I cheated.

After I finished, I spent a while trying to get the theme.  I thought it must be something to do with death: 1, 19, and 22 across contain DEAD, CHECKOUT, and PERISH. But the rest of the puzzle gave me nothing...

I'm glad I was wrong!  This was just a fine themeless.

Seems to me that there is a recent trend to offer fearsome-looking grids that turn out to be paper tigers.

The long entries often are gimmes or suggest themselves with only a couple of crosses.

Is this a constructor's choice or an editorial policy push?
Either way ensures fast times.

That picture is 30 years worth of memories! Grew up nearby and started going to the MOA when it first opened. The blog plus the puzzle is pure sentimental feels for me! Thanks! 

I survived working retail sat MOA when Britney, Justin Timberlake, and other weekends of teen bopper groups. 

If you know you know. But do you know the sound of 1000 screaming teen girls in a three story atrium?

A classy, classic kind of puzzle, thoughtful and thought provoking.  The whole thing fit like a toasty overcoat on a sunny winter walk in a different town, but a real town, not some cooked up paper concoction. I especially liked that there were no baldfaced gimmes (well, maybe one or so), but no fills so far out as to be ungettable by a normal person who could read the crosses and figure it out.

Thank you Adrian Johnson.  I had one look-up at the very end of the puzzle (SOBA), and I guessed that what I had was wrong, but hadn't a clue about what was right‚Äîthe one exception in the puzzle.  Please give us more.

Comments to the Sunday crossword creator's comments?  THIS is the nerdiest part of NYT.com, but I'm so glad I found it (at last).  So much more enjoyable to read than all the flamethrowing over the latest David Brooks column.  Happy holidays everyone!

At 25:15, a Sunday PB by a significant margin. I blanked for a bit on 1A, which I used to be a huge fan of, but 91A popped right into my head with no letters (the length was a giveaway). A very fun Sunday puzzle.

for those of us who look forward to a clever sunday theme, a themeless puzzle on a sunday is disappointing. there's nothing wrong with today's puzzle, but it feels more like a long wednesday than a sunday. though as a child of the 70s, i did appreciate the appearance of lite brites. üôÉ

i am also astounded by the continuing hate being poured on for last sunday's art heist puzzle. i thought it was great fun!

Only the Z is missing :(

Nice Sunday morning puZZle, thanks 

Rheas are better than Emus
Bonus points for the first person to use "Cocker Terriusky" as a clue with the 4 letter answer of MUTT

Anybody else prematurely congratulate themself after filling 97A with CHRISTMASCARDS? 
A perfect fit, and the cross with 85D FRIDA confirmed it for me. Woulda been a PB, I‚Äôm pretty sure!
Nice and breezy. Perfect for a pre-jog Sunday morning! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Vow Renewal for DINNER DATE

Nanas for AUNTS

Estonia for BELARUS

Lots of wrong first guesses, but still PDQ. 

Good puzzle.

My first clean Sunday solve. Took about an hour and was really enjoyable. Felt like a big Wednesday. I'm glad that they're a little less intimidating once in a while. It's a confidence boost for us noobs.
A personal best for a Sunday puzzle by quite a lot! I‚Äôll take it!

Ah, puzzle-induced trips down the memory lane‚Ä¶ My parents never took me bowling because my mother couldn‚Äôt abide the idea of (horrors) renting a pair of SHOES someone else had worn. (We all have our phobias.) So, sophomore year, I (secretly) signed up for a bowling class and, for one joyous semester, myself and three girlfriends all of whose names ended in -ie traipsed out a side door and across the road to a bowling alley to experience bliss (because bliss it was). Afterwards, the three -ie‚Äôs and I would traipse out the bowling alley door and across the road again, but then double back to an ice cream shop for the kind of giant sundaes only a Utah ice cream parlor has ever made. 

Of course we cut Health to do it, and eventually our absence on sex ed day was noted‚Äî‚Äòcause that day signatures to our awareness of the evi‚Ä¶er‚Ä¶ dangers of all that were required. The abstinence pledge was optional. Not really. 

Parents were called, messages were left on answering machines, which were promptly erased prior to said parents‚Äô getting home, of course, but then letters were sent and not all of them were successfully intercepted, what with 15-year old brains forgetting to check the mailbox every day. Then epistolary missives were sent in the other direction on the evi‚Ä¶ er‚Ä¶ dangers of letting children learn an other-people‚Äôs-shoe sport in lieu of mandatory tennis. 

Ah, the 90s. What a time it was. Thank you, Adrian Johnson, for the memory. 

(I can still bowl 200 if I‚Äôm showing off.)

PB for me with 29:13, and even more exciting, my first Sunday with no look ups whatsoever. Despite a grid that seems daunting initially with 14-letter answers, things slowly but surely fell into place

That‚Äôs two disappointing Sundays in a row for me. Last week‚Äôs for being too gimicky and this week for just the opposite. There was nothing wrong with this puzzle but it just felt like a big Wednesday. I look forward to a Sunday theme all week so this made me sad.

The FTW/WRYER crossing was my undoing, otherwise pretty smooth sailing. Ali and I reviewed  the puzzle extensively and could not locate the error.  Never heard of FTd, but dRYER just seemed correct.  For some reason I feel like I‚Äôve made this mistake before.  Those who forget the past are doomed‚Ä¶
Everybody's saying how easy this was - and I needed like 20 or 30 lookups for the trivia ü§£. Once I got the that out of the way though I filled the grid very quickly.
Kind of annoying to end up on a natick crossing two American brands I‚Äôve never heard of: a drink brand and a toy brand‚Ä¶

Even after revealing the answer, I do not connect ‚Äúinitiation of online excitement‚Äù with the answer ‚ÄúFTW‚Äù. Does this acronym mean, ‚Äúfor the win‚Äù? In that case, initiation, how? What is being initiated? A winning play of some kind? Why is it exclusively online? Maybe I am missing a pop culture reference in my dotage? And so on. Overall, today was a quiet relief from last week‚Äôs jangled mess.

Since it didn't occur to me that this could be a themeless Sunday, I thought I was missing something.  Post solve, I spent a few minutes trying to tie the puzzle to the title.  Doh!

Nice shoutout at 44 D to last weeks masterpiece.

@Nancy  A few years ago at a doctor‚Äôs office waiting room the patient next to me was doing the NYT crossword in pen. It happened to be a Friday. I commented about his doing it in pen. The fellow misogynist replied I let my wife do the easy days, M-W, and she uses pencil. As far as I know, they‚Äôre still married!
A filler-inner. No theme. What was the point?
This puzzle's flow had no glow.
Just too easy‚Ä¶

Easy for a Sunday? Yes. A relief after last Sunday? Also yes. 

This puzzle was so enjoyable. Wheelhouse activated!!! 

My trip to MALAGA made 81D a gimme.  EQUATORIALGUINEA was the payoff for being a geography nerd, as was BELARUS.  

I never heard of SCHNOODLE, but I figured the ending was an ~OODLE.  I almost took a friend‚Äôs LabraDOODLE but my daughter advised me against it.  She‚Äôs a veterinary nurse and pet sitter. She said the ‚Äúdoodles‚Äù are quite crazy and neurotic. I‚Äôve been to some of her pet sitting jobs where the client had doodles, and I must concur, though the sample size is admittedly small.

Anyway, a refreshing palate cleanser of a Sunday puzzle!

Rudolph the red knows rain, dear. 

Where was I? Oh yeah - not anywhere near a record time for me - just a typical Sunday workout. And I spent a good long while off and on near the end trying to grasp what the theme was. A themeless Sunday just never occurred to me. No big deal.

Might put a puzzle find in a reply. 

..

Even though this was my best Sunday time, there were a few things I didn‚Äôt know. Or once knew and forgot?

ESTELLE
CETUS
PINKBERRY
SOBE
What goes in a BELLINI

The clue for BROCODE was fun (still need to rewatch The Big Lebowski), and LITEBRITE and SHEL are among my favorite things about my childhood.
It's a cold, rainy Sunday morning in Paris - and a perfect time for this charming puzzle with a caf√© au lait. Thanks for a fun 39 minutes!

This felt smooth as butter to me.  Relaxing. I didn‚Äôt fly through it, as I often do early in the week, which can feel electric, but not tranquil.  Nor was It full of hitches, like driving on a rutty road.

No, this was soothing, like tubing down the river.  And that felt good.  Enough resistance to keep interest and motivation, enough open doors to make the forward progress feel like a glide.  Ahhh.

What helped was kind cluing and the low number of out-of-wheelhouse answers, at least for me.

I love the swirly grid design ‚Äì never used before in the Times puzzle -- even with the suggestion of a Superman S in the middle, and with many long answers (the normal Sunday has 140 words, this one has 124).  Even with the long answers, it‚Äôs cleanly filled, a testament to Adrian‚Äôs grid-building chops.    

Lovely answers enhanced the journey: PERISH THE THOUGHT, VANITY CASE, SCHNOODLE, TEARJERKER, PEWTER, and the fetching EQUATORIAL GUINEA.  I liked seeing FORA near FORABIT, and ALTERNATE ENDING abutting the actual ending.

You sent me peacefully and placidly into my day, Adrian, for which I‚Äôm most grateful.  Thank you!

I did this is an hour and 38 mins, since so many people are mentioning times. That's quite good considering I knew not one single brand name or proper name or film reference and went over the whole crossword multiple times checking crossers, guessing from what letter might be next, and revealing 6 squares. 

I had the B but would never have guessed PARTB was something to do with ambulances or that there are T TOP cars. 

It was frustrating with SRS related to a J - I was thinking elderly people, and juniors in the UK refers to children aged 7-11!

Yesterday's puzzle was so obscure for me that I didn't enjoy it one bit.

Today's themeless (Where's the theme? I kept asking myself) was so quick and easy that I couldn't believe it was a Sunday puzzle. And for that reason I didn't enjoy it. Oh, maybe a tad more enjoyable than yesterday's.

Nancy in NY said that Will is coming back. When oh when???

nice one today--not too easy, and not too hard. took some time but didn't have to do any lookups, the clues felt puzzly instead of just obscure knowledge, and very satisfying to figure out. 
loved 50A, 60A, 95A in particular!
Disappointed. I was hoping for a nice Christmas puzzle.
Hens SET on eggs, not sit.
I love a theme-less puzzle.  Just a fun solve, no tricks!

Just finished Barbara and Lewis' gem from yesterday.  I'll get started on today's later.   Busy times.

I did indeed go with the flow, and it jelled smoothly. Seemed like a lot of American pop trivia, my sympathies toward our international solvers.

Pleasant run, moderate to low difficulty, seems like an apologia for last week's monstrously bad entry.

I, too, felt as if I was "going with the flow" the way this puzzle was constructed. Nice and smooth. Great start to the week...happy Sunday everyone!

I feel for the editors having to come up with a title for this one, with no theme for guidance. No PB for me, but well below my Sunday average. Never got stuck, just cruised along, one clue to the next. As the mayor of our least populous capital city, I'm not worried about losing that title to Pierre, since they have about six thousand on us. Woooohoooo, a record 28:36 for me!!  Exciting way to start a busy day of loading the sleigh to go over the mountains and through the woods!!

After learning about a new-to-me beverage, I went back to The Bee and put it in...to no avail.  The Bee doesn't honor The Puzzle entries, I see.  Among other flaws....

BURKA (pretty sure I have some company with that one)
OASES (for the poor marathon runners)

COCOAS? (Skiiers don't need no stinkin' cocoa!)

Our home was a LITEBRITE, Atari/Mario/Pacman, FroYo, and SCHNOODLE-free Zone.  Cat People.

Given PhysicsDaughter's life-long love affair with horses, I had great difficulty accepting JOGTROT (after attempting to enter CANTERshoot)...   Carter the Palomino does not do JOGTROT.

Enjoyed the solve even though those countries did not exist when *I* studied GEOgraphy in school.

Interesting reading for those who have never encountered (or don't remember encountering) a themeless Sunday NYT Crossword: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/03/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2018-11-04.html
Too easy. My dog could do this (he's very smart). NOT a sunday puzzle!
The W in FTW was the last to fill, the meaning of which did not occur to me until that happened (Kept thinking, "This is backwards!).  Good clean fun and thanks.

I'm kind of surprised that so many people seem to rely on a theme to help them solve a puzzle. The theme or title doesn't show up on my phone so I never know what it is or was til I finish. Am I missing something that tells what the theme is?

As Mean Old Lady notes: Mississippi Skiers need no stinking COCOAS... or snow, hills, lift lines, etc., etc.

I wanted WRYER ko wanted dRYER. I was right for once, thank you Santa.

Nice one Adrian.

Solved it in half the time I needed yesterday. Got to the end wondering what theme I had missed. Noticed bits of morbidity---DEAD, CHECKOUT, and PERISH---in the stack at the top. But in the stack at the bottom, only ENDING seemed to connect, and then only quite loosely. So I simply assumed the puzzle's theme had eluded me completely.

Knew the TV show at 1A and recalled LITEBRITES from my childhood, but never heard of PINKBERRY or ESTELLE, and didn't know BELLINI. Did well with the GEOgraphical names, of which there were quite a few: TAOS, BELARUS, EQUATORIALGUINEA, EXETER, BERLIN, PIERRE, MALAGA.

Especially liked the way that 85D "Surrealist Kahlo" for FRIDA linked to last Sunday's lovely puzzle.
Strands today was perfect for anyone suffering from Christmas Brain, which is just this side of "wet brain." Calmed me down. Thanks!

Might have been too easy, but sometimes I think the border between easy and hard is just how many pop culture references you get and how many you don't. And I was lucky in that there was very little pop culture here from the last 15 years. (I vaguely remember hearing "American Boy" in a clothing store somewhere, but that's all.)

But that's all prelude to me bragging that I have a new personal best time for Sunday: 13:50!

It appears I'm the rare bird who liked both last Sunday and this Sunday, albeit for different reasons.

Today was one of those where I felt the constructors brain was hard wired to my own. FWIW- under 16 minutes to solve. More importantly,  I had fun and got several smiles out of the clues, and never had to run to Google for help.

Last Sunday took me longer, and stumped me. No gold start. Such is life. Again, I got a series of smiles and didn't feel like anything was "stolen" from me.

I love a big open themeless, and this didn't disappoint. Was it too easy for Sunday? Maybe, but wooshing through the grid, top to bottom, getting those long ones with minimal crosses, was a lot of fun.  Thanks Mr. A. J.!

Actually, this was pretty flow-y -- so I went with the flow wherever I could.  And while a great theme on Sunday is always preferable to a themeless puzzle -- giving you a macro solution along with a lot of micro ones -- a nice flow-y themeless that requires some thought is preferable to a drab, tepid theme that allows your mind to wander.  I enjoyed this and was never either bored or impatient.

There was plenty I never heard of: LITES RITES; PORESTRIP (why does that sound sort of unappetizing?);  SOSE; ESTELLE (does she ever get confused with Adele?); MOANIN; and even SCHNOODLE (I wanted some sort of DOODLE, but I assume it's a cross between a schnauser (sp?) and a poodle.  And, btw, how the heck do you spell schnauser?  Don't want to leave the page.)

Which reminds me: Is SOSE correct?  I forgot to look.

Have you ever heard anyone say JOGTROT?.  I certainly haven't.
I thought the cluing here succeeded in being interesting, but only one clue was truly tricky.  Loved the clue for TEARJERKER.

One of the more enjoyable Sunday puzzles, but not one of the most memorable.  But it kept me engaged on a bitterly cold morning when I'm not going anywhere.
Seeing all the personal bests being reported today makes me wonder if this puzzle was the NYT‚Äôs holiday gift to the stat conscious solvers.

I didn't and still don't understand what the title means. I'm probably being dense but I have no idea. I'm sure it's very clever since it's Sunday, but without knowing, to me this was just an oddly simple themeless Sunday puzzle with quite a few water/sea related answers. But I'll take the extremely rare weekend gold star
Fun puzzle! yes, easier than many. This was a holiday gift after last weeks challenge! Merry Christmas, Happy Hannukah, and Happy kwanzaa to all....
This was much too easy for a Sunday puzzle, IMO.
Finished a Sunday all by myself!  Started last night and let it marinate. The best advice from #Deb Amlen.  Happy Sunday everyone!

Doh! All this time I've been writing letters to Satan.

That explains so much.

Lovely Sunday themeless.

Finished the puzzle, but got the dreaded error message; doubly dreaded on a Sunday, when there's so much puzzle to re-examine.  Where did I goof?

At first, I though it was in the zone in the south.  Water-BORNE?  Certainly possible, but not necessary.  But all the crosses were clear.

JELL and JOG TROT?  Again, suspicious, but crosses seemed to tell me I was good.

Oh!  Now I see it!  "Tradition at the end of a graduation ceremony".  I initially had entered hAt TOSS, but corrected the first letter to a C, but failed to correct the third letter.

Certainly we're all familiar with the tradition of the graduation CAt TOSS!
On the easy side? Maybe. But sometimes you just need an easy win - and boy, after the past week, this is just what I needed. Thanks to the author for a fun puzzle!
What a nice Christmas gift! Thanks Mr. AJ! Good puzzle, great clues, fun fun fun!
My kind of puzzle - no tricks or mind-bending ‚Äúcreative‚Äù layers, just words and phrases.  On the easy side but a fun solve.  Thank you!

What a great puzzle outing! Go with the flow, indeed! The answers just flowed right into the grid, effortlessly, for a new PB. 

Time well spent! Thanks, Mr. A. J.

Fun to see ‚ÄúMoanin‚Äù clued.  It was written in 1958 for Art Blakey‚Äôs Jazz Messengers by its pianist at the time, Bobby Timmons.  Timmons also wrote two companion hits, ‚ÄúDis Here‚Äù and ‚ÄúDat There,‚Äù for Cannonball Adderley‚Äôs group.
Sad to say, Timmons died way too young from liver disease.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Sunday from February 13, 1972 by Bert Rosenfield with the title: "On cloud nine." That would have the eve of Valentine's day that year, so I guess that was the basis for the theme. Just seemed a bit.. odd. Anyway - 24 answers in that puzzle that appeared for the first and only time. 13 other answers that were appearing for the first time (and several of them only ever appeared in one other puzzle). And 16 more that never appeared in a Shortz era puzzle. Anyway... the theme seemed to partly revolve around VALENTINE (or near homonyms). Three answers being: MYFUNNYVALENTINE JIMMYVALENTINE RUDOLPHVALENTINO And - the other part of theme was 'heart' or near homonyms for that word. Some examples; SENVANCEHARTKE RODGERSANDHART HEARTSOFCELERY DEARHEART And then you can add: GOVERNORJOHNLOVE and SWEETSTOTHESWEET And then you can toss in a number of non-theme answers that were appearing for the first and only time. @Ken 

There should be a little information icon (a circled lower case i) at the top of your puzzle screen.  When the circle is flashing, there is a title or other information to be seen.

Today, the title is "Go With the Flow," but it is an unthemed puzzle.  

During the rest of the week, there are no titles.  However, the theme is either apparent (as is the case when each theme answer shifts to another vowel, such as BAT, BET, BIT, etc.), or there is a revealer, which is a long answer, usually near the bottom, that ties everything together.

Monday through Wednesday are generally themed puzzles; Thursdays are themed with some kind of trick, and Fridays and Saturdays are unthemed, harder puzzles.

Hope this helps!

@Robin It's both textile and pattern, actually. The Dictionaries of the Scots Language opens its definition of the word with: "A woollen cloth woven in stripes of varying width and colour repeated at regular intervals and crossing a similar set of stripes at right angles so as to form a pattern. A plaid or long blanket of this sort was the characteristic garb of Highlanders and certain patterns were favoured in certain districts perhaps because of the availability of local vegetable dyes." A useful bit then follows about how "almost entirely unhistorical" the confected "clan tartans" are, and finally we get a long-delayed semicolon and the additional definition, "a tartan pattern, esp. one associated with a particular clan". https://dsl.ac.uk/entry/snd/tartan So the pattern derives, in abstract, from the patterned cloth.
